text1: Youths w/ clinical anxiety exhibit distinct brain activation states during socioemotional processing, spending more time in a state associated with high ventral attention and default mode network activation when viewing negative content. https://t.co/jyrPGZ3jsK @BarchDbarch https://t.co/T02oJUqj8K
text2:
New research on youth anxiety! ğŸ§  We identified 3 distinct brain activation states during socioemotional processing using fMRI in 620 youths (5-15yrs).  Higher generalized anxiety linked to more time in a "default mode" state during negative stimuli.  Implications for intervention!

text1: Most medical conditions are associated with an increased risk of suicide in a dose-response manner, with the risk being particularly elevated for individuals with prior mental disorders. https://t.co/cWp8BkdkCE https://t.co/GEepgmI5kg
text2:
New research on suicide risk!  We analyzed data from 6,635,857 individuals in Denmark (2000-2020) and found that most medical conditions significantly increased suicide risk.  A dose-response relationship was observed for those without prior mental disorders.  Read more: [link to paper]

text2:

text1: Viewpoint describes both the current barriers patients face when filling their prescriptions for buprenorphine at pharmacies and a list of proposed fixes requiring changes at the federal, state, insurance, and clinician level. https://t.co/G54Akf5AIi https://t.co/IS5AnAbJzF
text2:
New research in JAMA Psychiatry reveals significant barriers to accessing buprenorphine, a life-saving medication for opioid use disorder.  A West Virginia study found 34% of patients had trouble filling prescriptions in the past year!  This is impacting patient recovery & increasing overdose risk. Let's address these systemic issues.

text1: Private equity (PE) firms own nearly 30% of US opioid treatment programs, exceeding PE penetration in other sectors of health care. https://t.co/nR2IIfcYEX https://t.co/dhCYVjA3V8
text2: NEW RESEARCH: Private Equity's impact on US Opioid Treatment Programs.  Our study reveals 29.1% of OTPs are PE-owned, with significant market concentration.  PE-owned OTPs were more prevalent in areas with higher White populations & lower incomes. text1: Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) show limited correspondence between genetic risk factors and current psychiatric drug targets. https://t.co/gODg5okSzA https://t.co/NI4BDQocmG
text2:
New research links GWAS & pharmacological treatments for psychiatric disorders!  We investigated 4 disorders (ADHD, bipolar, schizophrenia, MDD) using 2232 DrugBank genes & 4 bioinformatic modalities.  Significant link found for bipolar disorder via PPI network (P-permâ€‰=â€‰7â€‰Ã—â€‰10â»â´).  Overall correspondence was low, suggesting distinct genetic architectures.

text1: This RCT found no group-level evidence supporting neurofeedback as a stand-alone treatment for ADHD. https://t.co/46jaxL8Wq0 https://t.co/wbONeTDBte
text2:
New meta-analysis on neurofeedback for ADHD!  ğŸ¤”  38 RCTs (n=2472) showed no significant benefit overall.  However, a small positive effect was seen with standard protocols (SMD 0.21) and improved processing speed (SMD 0.35).  Implications for future research are discussed.
